Deare friend,</br>No more a Stranger now:  I lately past</br>Thy curious Building; call'd; but then my haste</br>Deny'd me a full draught; I did but taste.
Thy Wine was rich and pleasing; did appeare</br>No common grape:  My haste could not forbeare</br>A second sippe; I hung a Garland there:
Past on my way; I lasht through thick and thinne,</br>Dipatch'd my business, and return'd agen;</br>I call'd the second time; unhors'd, went in:
View'd every Room; each Room was beautifi'd</br>With new Invention, carv'd on every side,</br>To please the common and the curious ey'd:
View'd every Office, every Office lay</br>Like a rich Magazen; and did bewray</br>Thy Treasure, op'ned with thy golden key:
View'd every Orchyard; every Orchyard did</br>Appeare a Paradise, whose fruits were hid</br>(Perchance) with shadowing Leaves, but none forbid:
View'd every Plot; spent some delightful houres</br>In every Garden, full of new-born flowers,</br>Delicious banks, and delectable bowers.
Thus having stepp'd and travell'd every staire</br>Within, and tasted every fruit that's rare</br>Without; I made thy house my thorough-fare.
Then give me leave, rare Fletcher, (as before</br>I left a Garland at thy Gates) once more</br>To hang this Ivie at thy Postern-doore.</br>
